Section 8904 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to require health benefits plans to cover diagnosis and treatment of infertility, including assisted reproductive technology, with no greater copayment or deductible than obstetrical benefits. The individual must have coverage for appropriate infertility treatments, the procedure must be done at accredited medical facilities, and any required laboratory services must be provided by an accredited laboratory. The individual must have coverage for infertility treatments at accredited facilities. Coverage for certain procedures is limited to a maximum of 4 attempts for live birth or oocyte retrieval, with exceptions for successful live births. Coverage for infertility treatments is limited to a maximum of 4 attempts for live birth or oocyte retrieval, with exceptions for successful live births. If a live birth results from the fourth attempt, the lifetime maximum is increased to 6. The term 'infertility' is defined as the inability to conceive after 12 months of regular sexual relations or a demonstrated condition causing infertility. Nonexperimental assisted reproductive technology procedures include in vitro fertilization and other clinical treatments. The Office will prescribe regulations for recognized clinical treatments or procedures for infertility as defined by national organizations or Federal agencies. The amendment made by this Act will apply to contracts entered into or renewed for any year starting after a 6-month period from the date of enactment.
